Name: Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid
Description: Perfluorooctane-1-sulfonic acid is a perfluoroalkanesulfonic acid that is octane-1-sulfonic acid in which all seventeen of the hydrogens that are attached to carbons hvae been replaced by fluorines. It has a role as an antilipemic drug and a persistent organic pollutant. It is functionally related to an octane-1-sulfonic acid.

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Giesy JP, Kannan K; Environ Sci Technol 36: 147A-152A (2002)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid has been measured in blood sera of Laysan albatross (Phoebastria immutabilis) and Blackfooted albatross (P. nigripes) from the Midway Atoll in the North Pacific at concentrations of 3-26 ng/L(1). Blood samples from cormorants (Phalacrocorax auritus) and herring gulls (Larus argentatus) from the Great Lakes showed a 10-fold increase over that for the albatrosses(1). Blood plasma from 200 day old eagles (Aquila chrysaetos) from the Midwestern United States contained perfluorooctane sulfonic acid up to 2,570 ng/mL, with detectable levels >100 ng/mL reported in other fish-eating birds such as pelicans (Pelecanus erythrorhynchos) and loons (Gavia immer)(1). Concentrations in the eggs of Caspian terns (Hydroprogne caspia) from Lake Michigan waters were as great as 3,350 ng/g(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Sinclair E et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 50: 398-410 (2006)
animal_concentrations.Value: Mean concentrations in waterfowl livers collected from the Niagara River region of New York State in July of 2004(1).

animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctane sulfonate was measured in 161 samples of liver, kidney, blood, or egg yolk from 21 species of fish-eating water birds collected in the United States, including albatrosses (Laysan albatross (Diomedea immutabilis); black-footed albatross (D. nigripes)) from Sand Island, Midway Atoll, in the central North Pacific Ocean. Concentrations of perfluorooctane sulfonate in the blood plasma of bald eagles (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) collected from the midwestern United States ranged from 13 to  2,220 ng/mL (mean: 330 ng/mL); concentrations of perfluorooctane sulfonate were greater in blood plasma than in whole blood. Among 82 livers from various species of birds from inland or coastal U.S. locations, Brandt's cormorant (Phalacrocorax penicillatus) from San Diego, CA, contained the greatest concentration of perfluorooctane sulfonate (1,780 ng/g, wet wt). Perfluorooctane sulfonate was also found in the sera of albatrosses from the central North Pacific Ocean at concentrations ranging from 3 to 34 ng/mL. Occurrence of perfluorooctane sulfonate in birds from remote marine locations suggests widespread distribution of perfluorooctane sulfonate and related fluorochemicals in the environment. Data were collected over 1991 to 1998(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Giesy JP, Kannan K; Environ Sci Technol 36: 147A-152A (2002) (2) Kannan K et al; Environ Sci Technol 35: 1593-98 (2001) (3) Li X et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 7078-7083 (2008) (4) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-431 (2007) (5) Butt CM et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 3521-3528 (2007) (6) Hart K, et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 7132-7137 (2008) (7) Hart K et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 56: 607-614 (2009)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid has been measured in mink (Neovison vison) livers from the Midwestern United States with concentrations ranging from 40-5,140 ng/g(1). Concentrations in the river otters (Lontra canadensis) collected in Oregon ranged from 33.6 to 329 ng/g(2). Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid mean plasma concentrations in mammals were reported as follows (genus species, location, concentration in ng/mL or ng/g wet weight): Amur tiger, Panthera tigris altaica, China, 1.41; polar bear, Ursus maritimus, Svalbard,1290; bottlenose dolphin, Tursiops truncates: Bermuda, 49; Indian River Lagoon, FL, 642; New Jersey, 751; Sarasota Bay, FL 780; Charleston, SC, 1315; giant panda, Ailuropoda melanoleuca, Beijing, China, 11.10; red panda, Ailurus fulgens, 15.65(3). Concentrations in various Japanese animals sampled in February 2005 were 35-238, 19-33, 25-61, and 0.15-13 ng/g wet weight for cormorant, racoon dog, eagle, and large-bill crow, respectively(4). Levels in thick-billed murres (Uria lomvia) sampled from 1975, 1993 and 2004 were not detected, 0.51 and 0.75 ng/g wet weight, respectively; levels in northern fulmars (Fulmaris glacialis) from 1975, 1987, 1993, and 2003 were not detected, 0.17, 0.57, and 0.4 ng/g wet weight, respectively. Both species are residents of Prince Leopold Island in the Canadian Arctic(5). Concentrations in melon-head whales (Peponocephala electra) stranded along the Japanese coast in 1982, 2001/2002, and 2006 were reported as 4.6 to 10.2, 17.8 to 117, and 49.2 to 60.6 ng/g met weight, respectively(6). Mean concentration trends from 1992-2007 in livers from northern sea otters (Enhydra lutris kenyoni) from South-Central Alaska were 2.3, 1.6, 10.4, 2.7, 6.0, 4.2, 5.1, 10.8, 21.2, 7.0, 4.2, <0.9, 1.3, 1.9, and 2.8 ng/g wet wt(7).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Giesy JP, Kannan K; Environ Sci Technol 36: 147A-152A (2002) (2) Dai J et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5647-53 (2006) (3) Kannan K et al; Environ Sci Technol 35: 1593-98 (2001) (4) Dorneles PR et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5368-73 (2008)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid has been measured in the blood of grey seal (Halichoerus grypus) and ringed seal (Pusa hispida) from remote Norwegian and Canadian arctic at concentrations ranging from 3-50 ng/mL(1). A 2- to 10-fold increase (14-230 ng/mL) has been measured in seals from more contaminated locations, in this case, the Baltic Sea(1). Livers of Alaskan polar bears (Ursus maritimus) contain 180-680 ng/g wet weight perfluorooctane sulfonic acid(1). Concentrations in Weddell seals (Leptonychotes weddellii) taken from the Antarctic were below the detection limit of 35 ng/g(1). The compound was detected at concentration ranges of 0.80-73.80 ug/L and 0.76-19.00 ug/L in serum from captive red panda (Ailurus fulgens) and giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca), respectively, in China(2). The compound was present in 247 tissue samples from 15 species of marine mammals collected from 1991 through 2000 from Florida, California, and Alaska coastal waters; the northern Baltic Sea, the Arctic (Spitsbergen); and the Sable Island in Canada. The maximum concentrations in liver and blood were 1,520 ng/g in a bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops sp.) from Sarasota Bay, FL and 475 ng/mL in a ringed seal from the Bothnian Sea, respectively(3). Liver samples from 29 stranded marine tucuxi dolphins (Sotalia guianensis) from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil varied from 43-2431 ug/g dry weight in dolphins from the severely polluted Guanabara Bay to 76-427 ug/g dry weight in other less polluted area waters(4).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Tomy GT et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 4076-4081 (2009) (2) Tomy G et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 6475-6481 (2004) (3) Smithwick M et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 24: 981-986 (2005)
animal_concentrations.Value: Relative percentages of perfluorooctane sulfonic acid to total perfluorinated compounds in a western Canadian Arctic marine food web were reported as follows: arctic copepod (Calanus hyperboreus) 78; pelagic amphipod (Themisto libellula) 97; Artico cisco (Coregonus autumnalis) 98; Pacific herring (Clupea pallasi) 90; Arctic cod (Boreogadus saida) 83; ringed seal (Phoca hispipa) 98; beluga (Delphinapterus leucas) 75. Samples were collected from 2004-2005(1). The range ofconcentrations of perfluorooctane sulfonic acid in an eastern Arctic marine food web were reported as follows (ng/g wet weight; detection limit = 0.06 ng/g): zooplankton 1.1-2.6; clams (Mya truncata; Serripes groenlandica) 0.08-0.6; shrimp (Pandalus borealis; Hymenodora glacialis) not detected-0.9; Arctic cod (Boreogadus saida) 0.3-4.7; deepwater redfish (Sebastus mentella) not detected-6.3; walrus (Odobenus rosmarus) 1.4-3.6; narwal (Monodon monoceros) 5.4-17.7; beluga (Delphinapterus leaucas) 9.8-15.8; black-legged kittiwake (Rissa tridactyla) 1.2-20; glaucous gulls (Larus hyperboreus) 9.9-33.2(2). Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid mean concentration in liver tissue from East Greenland polar bears (Ursus maritimus) was reported as 2,470 ng/g wet weight(3).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Kannan K et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 48: 559-566 (2005)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid in aquatic organisms at various trophic levels in a Great Lakes food chain, 1998-2001(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Nakata H et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 4916-4921 (2006) (2) Houde M et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 9397-9403 (2008)
animal_concentrations.Value: Mean concentrations in shallow water organisms during 1999 and 2004 from the Ariake Sea, Japan were (ng/g wet wt): file fish 0.84; sea bream 8.4; red sea bream 9.7; right eye flounder 65; hammerhead shark 18; finless porpoise 278; mallard 375; blackheaded gull 301. In tidal flat organisms from the same region, mean concentrations were (ng/g wet wt): oyster <0.3; mussel <0.3; clam <0.3; lugworm 0.41; crab <0.3; mudskipper (herbivourous) 1.2; mudskipper (omnivorous) 0.77. Levels in the associated sediment ranged from 0.09 to 0.14 ng/g dry wt(1). Analysis of a typical Lake Ontario food web resulted in the following mean concentrations (log, ng/g wet wt): zooplankton 0.2; Mysis 0.9; Diporeia 1.8: alewife 1.7; smelt 1.9; sculpin 2.7; lake trout 1.7(2).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Tao L et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 7642-7648 (2006)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid concentrations (ng/g liver wet weight) in albatrosses (genus Diomedea) from the Southern Ocean and North Pacific Ocean(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Giesy JP, Kannan K; Environ Sci Technol 36: 147A-152A (2002) (2) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-431 (2007) (3) Squadrone S et al; Environ Monit Assess 187: 438 (2015). Available from, as of Mar 23, 2016: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26085281
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid concentrations in the livers of blue-fin tuna (Thunnus sp.) from the Mediterranean Sea were as high as 87 ng/g(1). The compound was not detected in yellow-fin tuna (Thunnus sp.) liver samples taken from the North Pacific(1). Concentrations in fish tissues from the Great Lakes and the Mediterranean Sea contain 10-500 ng/g perfluorooctane sulfonic acid, with 300 ng/g reported in muscle of carp (Catostomus sp.) collected from Saginaw Bay, MI(1). Concentrations in eggs of brown trout (Salmo trutta) from Michigan waters were as high as 250 ng/g(1). Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid concentrations from Japanese fish sampled in February 2005 were reported as follows (ng/g wt weight; detection limit = 0.08): Scad (Decapterus maruadsi) <8.7; Sand fish (Arctoscopus japonicus) <7.4; Jack Mackerel (Trachurus japonicus) 1.6; Rainbow trout (Salmo gairdneri) <7.4.5; Sardine (Sardinops sp.) <7.3(2). Perfluorooctane sulfonic acid was detected in muscle tissue of European perch (Perca fluviatilis) taken from Lake Varese, Italy at maximum concentrations of 17.2 ng/g(3).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) ESFA; Perfluoroalkylated substances in food: occurrence and dietary exposure. European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), Parma, Italy. EFSA Journal 2012. 10: 2743 (2012). Available from, as of March 29, 2016: https://www.efsa.europa.eu/sites/default/files/scientific_output/files/main_documents/2743.pdf
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Food occurrence data for perfluorooctane sulfonic acid (PFOS) and other perfluoroalkylated substances were collected in 13 European countries during the period 2006 to 2012. A total of 54,195 analytical results were obtained for 7,560 food samples. PFOS was quantified in 29% of all food samples with fish and other seafoods having the most frequent detections(1).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Bao J et al; Chemosphere 77: 652-57 (2009) (2) Bao J et al; Chemosphere 80: 123-30 (2010) (3) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-31 (2007) (4) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for Perfluoralkyls. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2015). Available from, as of March 23, 2016: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp (5) Long ER et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 32: 1701-10 (2013) (6) Guo C et al; Chemosphere 127: 201-7 (2015)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Perfluoroctane sulfonic acid concentration in sediments collected in April 2008 from the Daliao River system of northeast China ranged from below the detection limit of 0.12 to 0.37 ng/g dry weight. The watershed is situated in a heavily populated and industrialized region(1). Median concentrations in river sediments collected in March 2009 from 13 sites in the Zhujiang River, Guangzhou and 9 sites in the Hunagpu River, Shanghai (China) were 0.58 and 0.11 ng/g dry weight, respectively(2). Median concentrations in river sediments collected in March 2009 from 13 sites in the Zhujiang River, Guangzhou and 9 sites in the Hunagpu River, Shanghai (China) were 0.21 and 0.43 ng/g dry weight, respectively(2). Concentrations in Japanese river sediments from the Kyoto region sampled in February 2005 were reported as follows (ng/g dry weight; detection limit = 0.8): Kamo River <1.9; Uji River Station 1: <0.33; Uji River Station 2: <1.4; Tenjin River 11; Katsura River <2.2; Osaka River Stations 1, 2, 3, and 4: <1.0, 3.8, 6.4, and <1.7, respectively(3). Perfluoroctane sulfonic acid was detected in 100% of sediment samples collected near the 3M Cottage Grove Facility, Minnesota at concentrations of 40.0-65,450 ng/g(4). It was detected in 80-82% of Mississippi River sediments at maximum levels of 3.16-79.0 ng/g(4). Perfluoroctane sulfonic acid was detected in 5 of 40 sediment sampling locations from the Puget Sound in 2010 at a concentration range of 0.18-0.23 ng/g dry wt(5). Sediments taken from Taihu Lake, East China contained levels of 0.13-6.95 ng/g dry wt(6).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for Perfluoralkyls. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2015). Available from, as of March 23, 2016: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp (2) Xiao F et al; Water Res 72: 64-74 (2015)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Perfluoroctane sulfonic acid was detected in 95% of soil samples collected near the 3M Cottage Grove Facility, Minnesota at maximum concentration of 104,000 ng/g(1). A median soil concentration of 12.2 ng/g was detected in a US metropolitan area(2).
